newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Yes, I killed the bears.
newsitem.headline: Yes, I killed the bears.

text.p: Prime Minister Viktor Chernomyrdin has provoked some rare outrage in the Russian media for shooting dead two bear cubs and their mother, aroused from winter hibernation.
Ogonyok magazine denounced the killing during the hunt last month as "akin to common murder".
Chernomyrdin was unabashed. "Hunting of bears is not banned, it's a normal thing," he said with a coy grin in an interview shown on national television on Sunday night.
"There was a female bear and two other smaller ones, but they were grown," he said.
The portly premier was responding to reports that he travelled by helicopter to a village north of Moscow last month after regional officials spotted a family of hibernating bears in their den.
Bear hunting is traditionally viewed as a way of proving a man's status as a "muzhik" -- a hearty, real Russian man -- and has rarely roused any public outcry.
But Chernomyrdin, a potential successor to ailing President Boris Yeltsin, found himself attacked by two magazines and independent NTV television's popular "Itogi" programme.
Ogonyok's latest issue gave a detailed account of the prime minister's hunting exploits and twisted the knife by illustrating it with pictures of cuddly baby cubs.

"One is overcome by a feeling of bitter vexation at the concept of the leaders of a country with great humanitarian ideals finding time for a hunt that is more akin to a common murder," it fulminated.
"I'd like to watch those who are writing about this meet those bears eye-to-eye to watch their reaction," Chernomyrdin retorted.
"I love hunting, I really love hunting, so it is with pleasure that I went when I had a free moment."
Past Soviet leaders including Leonid Brezhnev and Nikita Khrushchev were well known for their love of hunting. But they did not have to answer questions about their victims.
